statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Virginia Tech 72, Old Dominion 55
article.story: BLACKSBURG, Va. (AP) -- Virginia Tech ended the way it began, with teamwork to build a commanding lead. The Hokies (5-3) had three players in double figures as they defeated Old Dominion 72-55 on Wednesday night. The 17-point margin matched the 20-3 lead the Hokies built at the beginning of the game. "It was good to finish off a game," Virginia Tech coach Seth Greenberg said. "We had a lot of different contributors." Deron Washington scored 18 points, Zabian Dowdell had 17, Lewis Witcher 10 and Jamon Gordon 9 for the Hokies. Washington had seven rebounds as the Hokies outrebounded the Monarchs 37-28. Dowdell had six assists and Gordon had five. "It might have been our best team effort," Washington said. "Everyone was playing hard and playing together." Valdas Vasylius led the Monarchs (6-3) with 17 points and fouled out with about a minute and a half left in the game. Brian Henderson added 13 points for ODU. The Monarchs never led, tying the game only once at the beginning, but they narrowed the margin to 24-18 on a 15-4 run midway through the first half. Tech led 39-30 at intermission. "At halftime we told each other we had to come out and play hard in the second half so we didn't let them get back in the game," Gordon said. The Monarchs pulled to within 7 twice in the second half, making it 51-44 on a 3-pointer by Arnaud Dahi and then 57-50 on Henderson's 3-pointer with 7:30 left. A.D. Vassallo answered with a 3-pointer, followed by jumpers by Witcher, Gordon and Dowdell. The Hokies shot 46 percent on field goals to the Monarchs' 39 percent, but ODU connected on 10 of 26 3-pointers, compared to just 3 of 13 for Virginia Tech. The Hokies, who have struggled from the free-throw line, shot 65 percent Wednesday night, with Dowdell going 7-for-7 and Vassallo 4-for-4. The Monarchs committed 18 turnovers, 14 of them in the first half that the Hokies turned into 21 points. Virginia Tech had nine turnovers. "We were a little less than our best, but they were very good," Old Dominion coach Blaine Taylor said. The Hokies had 10 steals, nine of them in the first half. Washington and Gordon each had three, and Dowdell had two. The Hokies were without center Coleman Collins, who was sidelined with a leg bruise. ODU had won its last three meetings with the Hokies, who lead their series 13-7.
